itemDescription: Headmaster of Bedford School and a former English cricketer (born 1969)

wikipedia_page.main: James Simon Hodgson (born 1969) is the Headmaster of Bedford School and a former English cricketer.

response: *James Hodgson, cricketer and headmaster of Bedford School

Bedford School is composed of the Preparatory School (ages 7 to 13) and the Upper School (ages 13 to 18). There are around 1,100 pupils, of whom approximately one half are boarders. In 2014, James Hodgson succeeded John Moule as headmaster after he moved on as headmaster of Radley College, another independent school for boys.
* 2014–present James Hodgson (Wellington College; Cambridge University; Durham University)
*James Hodgson (cricketer, born 1969), headmaster of Bedford School and English cricketer
*James Hodgson (mathematician) (1672–1755), English mathematical teacher, lecturer and writer
James Hodgson (born 28 March 1972) is a former English cricketer.  Hodgson was a right-handed batsman who bowled leg break.  He was born at Reading, Berkshire.

Hodgson made his Minor Counties Championship debut for Berkshire in 1993 against Oxfordshire.  From 1993 to 1998, he represented the county in 33 Minor Counties Championship matches, the last of which came in the 1998 Championship when Berkshire played Oxfordshire.Minor Counties Championship Matches played by James Hodgson  Hodgson also played in the MCCA Knockout Trophy for Berkshire.  His debut in that competition came in 1994 when Berkshire played Buckinghamshire.  From 1994 to 1998, he represented the county in 6 Trophy matches, the last of which came when Berkshire played the Hampshire Cricket Board in the 1998 MCCA Knockout Trophy.  He also played a single List-A match for Berkshire against Lancashire in the 1997 NatWest Trophy.

In 2000, Hodgson represented the Kent Cricket Board in the 2000 MCCA Knockout Trophy, making his debut in that competition for the Board against the Surrey Cricket Board.  From 2000 to 2002, he represented the Board in 6 Trophy matches, the last of which came in the 2000 MCCA Knockout Trophy when the Board played the Channel Islands.Minor Counties Trophy Matches played by James Hodgson  Hodgson also represented the Board in 2 List-A matches, the first of which came against Warwickshire in the 2001 Cheltenham & Gloucester Trophy  His second and final List-A match for the Board came in the 2002 Cheltenham & Gloucester Trophy against Hampshire.List-A Matches played by James Hodgson  In his 3 List-A matches, he scored 104 runs at a batting average of 104.00 (so high due to 2 not out innings), with a high score of 53*.

Additionally, in 1991 Hodgson represented the Nottinghamshire Second XI in the Second XI Championship and Second XI Trophy.Second Eleven Championship Matches played by James HodgsonSecond Eleven Trophy Matches played by James Hodgson
Hodgson today plays club cricket for The Mote Cricket Club, based at Mote Park, in the Kent Cricket League.Kent Premier League Matches played by James Hodgson
